page.title: 11Dairy Farming in Bredfield
page.content: Cows have to be milked before the tanker comes in the morning, which can be as early as five o'clock. The second milking must not be more than fourteen hours later. A cow can be milked for three hundred days after she has had a calf, and then rests for sixty five days. At first she gives twenty two litres of milk a day, but it gradually gets less. A cow needs one hundred and ten litres of water a day at its best milking time. A cowman can look after a hundred cows, but it is hard physical work keeping everywhere clean as there is no machinery to do it. In summer outside cows eat grass and weeds, but in winter inside they eat hay, silage or cattlecake. The dairy farmers keep their hedges as windbreaks, and those in Bredfield also want to keep them and their meadows to conserve wildlife.
